cards.title: The New Review / Share your photographs on the theme of 'wave'
cards.rawTitle: Share your photographs on the theme of 'wave'

item.title: Your pictures: share your photographs on the theme of 'wave'
item.trailText: Wherever you are in the world, we’d like to see your pictures of ‘wave.’ Share your best photos via GuardianWitness
item.standFirst:
Wherever you are in the world, we’d like to see your pictures of ‘wave.’ Share your best photos via GuardianWitness

  • Readers’ pictures on the theme of ‘shine’
item.body:
We’re now running a regular weekly photography assignment in the Observer New Review and the next rather timely theme is ‘wave.’ So whether it’s a ripple in the ocean, flags swaying in the wind or a long goodbye, share your photos of what shine means to you – and tell us about your image in the description box.

The closing date is Thursday 4 June at 10 am. We’ll publish our favourites in The New Review on 7 June and in a gallery on the Guardian site.

You can share your ‘wave’ pictures by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments’ – and if you add it to the homepage – you can keep up with all our assignments.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others.

cards.title: Climate change / How are you campaigning?

item.title: Climate change: how are you campaigning?
item.trailText: Show us how you are committed to lobbying against climate change
item.standFirst: Show us how you are committed to lobbying against climate change
item.body:
We’d like to see your photos, videos and stories of how you are campaigning against climate change. How do you show your commitment? Do you participate in demonstrations or local campaign events? Are you influenced by your values when it comes to the things you buy? Perhaps you choose certain cars or there are foods you do (or don’t) eat? Whether you approach your activism through daily decisions or with campaigning zeal, we’d like to hear from you.

You can share your photos, videos and stories by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments.’

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.

cards.title: Photography / Show us your world with a photo
cards.rawTitle: Show us your world with a photo

item.title: Guardian Weekly: your week in photographs
item.trailText: We’d like see how things look from your perspective, wherever you live. Whether you’re caught up in a news event or have a personal experience you’d like us to know about, share your photos via GuardianWitness
item.standFirst: We’d like see how things look from your perspective, wherever you live. Whether you’re caught up in a news event or have a personal experience you’d like us to know about, share your photos via GuardianWitness
item.body:
Here at Guardian Weekly, we capture a week in the life of the world. From our very international perspective, we showcase news, political views, and the softer side of life. And we don’t do it alone.

We rely on readers to contribute observations from around the globe via our Letter from column. We delight in their wit and wisdom in Notes & Queries. And we enjoy knowing who they are, and how they spend their time, in our Good to meet you offering.

And now we’d like you to capture a week in the life of your world, in pictures. We’d like to see how things look from your perspective, wherever you live. Whether you’re caught up in a news event or have a personal experience to share, we’d like to see something exceptional from your week, in photos. Wherever you are in the world, please show us what you can see by joining in the 365 project on GuardianWitness. We’d also like to know if you’re a Guardian Weekly reader, so do tell us in the description box.

One photo a week will be published in the Guardian Weekly, in print on our Eyewitnessed photo montage, and online at theguardian.com/weekly.

You can contribute a photo every week, or send us something just once. It’s up to you – however the picture must be taken in 2015. Please do tell us about the image in the description box and let us know the date it was taken. We’re looking for striking images. With Weekly readers in more than 170 countries, who have experience in all walks of life, we know your snapshots will be amazing.

You can share your photos and stories by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the new Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments’.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site

cards.title: I'm wondering if I rushed into the first job offered
cards.rawTitle: I'm wondering if I rushed into the first job offered

item.title: I'm wondering if I rushed into the first job offered
item.trailText: It started well, but I’ve had little support and my confidence has taken some bad knocks. Should I get out?
item.standFirst: It started well, but I’ve had little support and my confidence has taken some bad knocks. Should I get out?
item.body:
Twice a week we publish problems that will feature in a forthcoming Dear Jeremy advice column in the Saturday Guardian so that readers can offer their own advice and suggestions. We then print the best of your comments alongside Jeremy’s own insights. Here is the latest dilemma – what are your thoughts?

I graduated last year with a first class bachelor’s degree in engineering, but because I was keen to avoid additional stress in the final months of my degree, I started the job search effectively a year before.

I applied to graduate schemes at four companies but only got to the interview stage for one. The company in question is one of the largest graduate employers in the UK and had great ratings on various review sites. I went to the assessment centre just before Christmas 2013 and was offered a job a week later. I was over the moon, accepted the job and didn’t think about applying to any more.

After graduating I started at the company and, initially, I had the excitement of the new job to drive me forward. But, after a few months, I find myself bogged down and struggling.

I expected to receive a lot of mentoring in the first year but, instead, I found myself thrust into a front-line role with no experience and little moral support from my colleagues. I tried to push myself harder but a series of incidents has severely affected my self-confidence. I’m now stuck in a vicious cycle of depression and stress which has made me wonder if I really want to stay in the role.

This is further compounded by performance-related pay, which all salaried employees are subject to. I like the concept, but the ad hoc way in which the management run it has made me terrified of screwing up.

I can’t help wondering if I made the right choice by rushing into the first job I was offered and whether or not I should get out.

Do you need advice on a work issue? For Jeremy’s and readers’ help, send a brief email to dear.jeremy@theguardian.com. Please note that he is unable to answer questions of a legal nature or to reply personally.

headerImage.caption: A reader is stressed at work. Photograph: Alamy
headerImage.cleanCaption: A reader is stressed at work.

cards.title: Football / Share your FC United of Manchester photos and stories
cards.rawTitle: Share your FC United of Manchester photos and stories

item.title: Open for business: share your FC United of Manchester photos and stories
item.trailText: FC United of Manchester officially open their new ground on Friday night with a high-profile friendly against Benfica. If you are attending the game or have other stories and photographs about the club to share, we’d like to hear from you
item.standFirst: FC United of Manchester officially open their new ground on Friday night with a high-profile friendly against Benfica. If you are attending the game or have other stories and photographs about the club to share, we’d like to hear from you
item.body:
FC United of Manchester officially open their new home at Broadhurst Park in Moston on Friday night when they welcome Benfica for a showcase friendly with a sell-out crowd of 4,000 expected in the stands. Formed 10 years ago after the Glazer family took over Manchester United, the fan-owned club have made great strides in the lower divisions of English football ever since, with four promotions achieved since 2005. If you are planning to attend the match, we’d like you to share your photos and memories of what the football club means to you.

How long have you supported FC United? Maybe you have been involved right from the start, and have followed the club’s progress from season to season. We’d also like to hear about the reasons you started supporting FC United and how far you think the club can go. Is promotion to the Football League in a couple of years a realistic target? Share your FC United photos and memories with us and we’ll feature the best of them on the site.

You can share your pictures and experiences by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or theGuardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments’ – and if you add it to the homepage – you can keep up with all our assignments.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others.

cards.title: Róisín Murphy webchat – post your questions now
cards.rawTitle: Róisín Murphy webchat – post your questions now

item.title: Róisín Murphy webchat – post your questions now
item.trailText: The electropop singer and former Moloko frontwoman will be answering your questions on Monday 1 June at 2pm BST – post yours in the comments
item.standFirst: The electropop singer and former Moloko frontwoman will be answering your questions live on Monday 1 June at 2pm BST – post yours in the comments below

blocks.title: Post your questions for Roisin Murphy
blocks.body:
Róisín Murphy made her entrance on to the pop stage in 1999, fronting the group Moloko, breaking into the charts with a sunkissed house remix of their track Sing It Back.

She later went solo, co-producing her 2005 debut album Ruby Blue with experimental musician Matthew Herbert, and following it with the dark electropop of 2007’s Overpowered.

She eased out of the spotlight after becoming a mother, but 2015 sees her back in a flurry of activity: earlier this year she released Mi Senti, an EP of covers of classic Italian pop songs, and earlier this month she released the album Hairless Toys, inspired by the 80s ball scene in New York. Murphy reanimates its world of outcast beauty with lounge ballads and strutting disco.

She’s joining us to answer your questions in a live webchat from 2pm on Monday 1 June – post yours in the comments below, and she’ll answer as many as possible.

keyEvents.title: Post your questions for Roisin Murphy
keyEvents.body:

She eased out of the spotlight after becoming a mother, but 2015 sees her back in a flurry of activity: earlier this year she released Mi Senti, an EP of covers of classic Italian pop songs, and earlier this month she released the album Hairless Toys, inspired by the 80s ball scene in New York. Murphy reanimates its world of outcast beauty with lounge ballads and strutting disco.

She’s joining us to answer your questions in a live webchat from 2pm on Monday 1 June – post yours in the comments below, and she’ll answer as many as possible.

cards.title: Payday loans / Have you been refused one?

item.title: Have you been refused a payday loan? Share your experiences
item.trailText: We’d like to find out if tougher rules on payday loans mean some borrowers are now being turned down by lenders. Share your experiences via GuardianWitness
item.standFirst: We’d like to find out if tougher rules on payday loans mean some borrowers are now being turned down by lenders. Share your experiences via GuardianWitness
item.body:
Tougher rules on payday loans are designed to stop consumers being ripped off, but the flipside is that some borrowers are now being turned down by lenders. We would like to find out what is happening to people who would previously have managed to get a payday loan.

Have you recently had an application rejected? Where did you turn instead?

You can share your experiences by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments.’

If you’d prefer to share anonymously, you can fill in the form below. You don’t need to supply your real name, but please do leave contact details if you’re happy for us to get in touch. You can also email us at guardian.witness@theguardian.com

We will use the most interesting contributions in our reporting.

displayImages.altText: The offices of Wonga, the payday loan company, near Regent's Park in London
